150385119.review:
One of the standout features of the game is its exceptional art design. The developers have managed to create a visually stunning and immersive environment that feels like a dark and twisted dream. The attention to detail in the character and level design is unparalleled, creating a world that is both unsettling and enchanting at the same time.

The gameplay itself is a perfect balance of suspense and exploration. Navigating through the ominous surroundings, solving puzzles, and overcoming obstacles feels both challenging and rewarding. The sense of vulnerability adds an extra layer of intensity to the experience, making every encounter with the grotesque inhabitants of the game world a heart-pounding affair.

Little Nightmares also excels in storytelling without relying on traditional narrative methods. The game unfolds its enigmatic plot through environmental storytelling and subtle hints, allowing players to piece together the narrative themselves. This clever approach adds an extra layer of depth to the overall experience, encouraging players to engage their minds as well as their reflexes.

The sound design deserves special mention, as it complements the eerie atmosphere perfectly. The haunting melodies and ambient sounds enhance the feeling of suspense, making every creak and groan in the environment contribute to the overall sense of dread.

In summary, Little Nightmares is a masterclass in atmospheric gaming. It manages to create a captivating and memorable experience that will linger in your mind long after you've put the controller down. Whether you're a fan of puzzle-platformers or simply appreciate a game that can evoke a wide range of emotions, Little Nightmares is an absolute must-play. It's a hauntingly beautiful journey that showcases the brilliance of indie game development.

150327612.review:
"Little Nightmares: My Impressions of This Masterful Game"

<3
Here's my impression of the game "Little Nightmares" after a brief but captivating gameplay experience.

"Little Nightmares" is a true embodiment of art in the world of video games. From the first moments of the game, you are captivated by an atmosphere of mystery and suspense. The game not only evokes fear but also creates a unique world where every step is a new discovery.

The graphics impress with their detail, atmosphere, and uniqueness. Each character and level has its own character and contributes to the overall mood of the game. The variety of tasks and puzzles keeps you on edge, and the music and sound design create a unique soundtrack to your adventure.

The gameplay is a separate narrative. Agility and logical thinking are crucial, and each level requires new skills and strategies. It's not just a game; it's interactive art that captivates your imagination and leaves you with plenty of impressions.

In "Little Nightmares," I found not just a game but an emotional and intellectual challenge. It's a work of art that will leave its mark in the memory of every player. And what particularly impresses me is the game's soundtrack, resembling a lullaby at night. The musical accompaniment in "Little Nightmares" seamlessly fits into the overall mood of the game and, like a lullaby, has the ability to immerse you in deep reflection, creating a sense of calm even amid horrors and mysteries.

Each melodic touch, adapted to the atmosphere of a specific level or moment in the game, resonates in my inner world, adding even more emotional nuance to the events. This musical approach emphasizes not only the terrifying side of the story but also makes it more profound and emotionally rich.

The soundtrack of "Little Nightmares" gives the impression of being in a large, living dream, where melodies intertwine with the visual aesthetics of the game, creating an incredibly harmonious and effective interactive experience. This lullaby symphony becomes an integral part of the impressions from "Little Nightmares" and enhances the overall gaming experience, making it even more unforgettable.

149783591.review:
I both love and hate Little Nightmares. If it wasn't so damn clunky and frustrating in its controls and bugs, it would be one of my favorite games of all time.

The environments and art direction are absolutely stunning--it's an absolute delight to look at despite its grotesque themes. The character designs are simultaneously disturbing and oddly charming, in a sort of Studio Ghibli's "Spirited Away" sort of way. The animations are fantastic--from the twitches of limbs, to the swinging of loose doors you climb, to the way the fish's bodies reacts to your mass as you walk over them--every little detail really helps to make this world feel alive. Despite the incredible, dark atmosphere however, Little Nightmares never really felt like a horror game. I wouldn't go in expecting to be spooked.

The game is less than two hours in length, which wouldn't be a bad thing in itself, but the final chapter didn't feel like much of a climax. It was way too rushed. You're presented with a new monster (the least interesting of them all) who's been hinted at throughout the game, but you have one brief chase sequence with it before a very simple final fight.

The worst part of the game, unfortunately, is the flow. You will most likely die to something that felt out of your control, maybe multiple times in a row. Near the beginning for example, you're taught to keep quiet to avoid a monster. You transition to a new room while being silent. He follows you in and immediately chases you as if he heard you, despite there being no indication (not even tense music).

The hurtboxes feel inaccurate. I died way too many times to collisions with enemies when I was clearly out of their reach. I must've died to the dining table level at least seven times, which completely kills any sort of tension. I've run into multiple bugs where I got stuck on the environment or an item disappeared and I had to reload.

So basically I wholeheartedly recommend the game. I just wish it had been perfected. It's one of the most beautiful games I've ever seen, just incredibly frustrating.

[h1]My Rating: 3/5[/h1]

149105498.review: This is one of the only horror games I have ever played, and I absolutely loved it. Introduced to the series by Markiplier some years ago, I played Little Nightmares 2 blind and was blown away. So much so that I came back and bought the original installment AND its DLC just to show my support for the franchise. I even got to play the DLC blind, and while the final few puzzles were a little bit of a roadblock on occasion, I don't regret sticking through it! The atmosphere, the grotesque imagery, the music, the tension! Before LN, I had made a point of only ever watching OTHERS play through horror games so I didn't have to, and yet even watching footage of the first game: I KNEW I wanted to play its sequel myself! Little Nightmares shies away from easy jumpscares and relies almost solely on atmosphere, imagery, and puzzles that make you do things your instincts really don't want you doing! It's oddly thrilling! Definitely worth picking up!

149051671.review:
I really enjoyed this game. The story-line is truly unsettling, and, since the story-telling is implicit (there are no cut-scenes, written text etc..) you have to look around to understand what is happening. The strangely comforting art-style of the game combined with its eerie atmosphere gave the game dimension and made me want to keep playing. 

The levels themselves were challenging (maybe it's also because I'm new to gaming), but not to the point that you had to rage-quit. The fact that you have to complete little side quests (which, btw, the game does not tell you about) to get the various achievements adds value to the game.

I do think that this game was intended to be played with a controller, though, as, sometimes, Six would not respond accurately to the keyboard movements. So, if you have a controller, definitely try playing this game with it. 

One thing is for sure, I wanna get the rest of the series :)

148773496.review:
I was very hesitant when considering to play this game, I knew nothing about it and was worried that it wasn't going to be worth my time and money but my curiosity got the best of me and I went in blind.

And I am so glad I did.

Little Nightmares is more than what it presents itself to be. On the surface it's a puzzle game with a dollhouse perspective set in an abstract and messy environment but if you dig deeper you can find layers of perspective on the games world and the story it is trying to convey.

Tarsier Studios (the developers behind Little Nightmares and Little Nightmares 2) were inspired by many different medians when creating this game and a prime example is with the film `Spirited Away` by Studio Ghibli with how they leave everything up to the interpretation of the audience.

There is no dialogue in this game but rather the narrative is displayed through visual storytelling as the player progresses, there's hidden details found throughout the background to give the player a better understanding of the world they live in, etc.

The set pieces, environment and level-design were intentionally made as if you were looking through the perspective of a child which is so cool! Objects will appear warped and distorted as well as the many creatures and humanoids you'll encounter on your journey through The Maw.

It's worth noting that this isn't a horror game but rather it can be an intense hide-and-seek game with (at certain times) unsettling elements to display that your character (Six) does not belong there.

The only con I can say for the game is that the field of depth can throw the player off at certain points, an example is if you're trying to run and jump to grab a chain you could end up missing it because the worlds perspective can be a little tricky to adjust to.

While a game like Little Nightmares may not be for everyone, this is an experience I often come back to replay and show my friends who love doing deep dives into theories with. If you love rabbit holes, open-ended storytelling, and/or games like LIMBO or INSIDE then I would recommend this to you!

148686853.review:
Little Nightmares is an amazing experience, but the gameplay itself has some problems and can be frustrating. If you are interested in the game because of the vibe you get from screenshots or trailers then I can easily recommend it. If, however, you play games more for the mechanics and don't care as much about art, sound, or story, then you may want to read further.

First, before I list my complaints, let me praise the game a bit more so that it's clear how much I liked it. It really is an incredible experience. The graphics are fantastic; it uses Unreal, but the art direction really sets it apart from other Unreal games. Everything has a very tactile feel, so that every creepy place you venture through feels like you are there. The sound effects amplify the already disturbing visuals, with the noises that the inhabitants make deserving special recognition. Playing Little Nightmares did make me feel both like there was some kind of dream/nightmare logic going on as well as like I was a little kid in a big world that I didn't understand. There are some scary moments (including a few really tense standout moments), but I think my main impression looking back was of being unsettled, uneasy, disturbed, and curious. There is no dialog and nothing is explained, so if you enjoy "environmental storytelling" where you have to try and piece together what is happening then this will be right up your alley.

Ok, now for the bad: I had _many_ frustrations playing this game. It felt like the game design was often at odds with the incredible experience I was having, ruining my immersion and making me frustrated and just wanting to get past something to see what happened next.

The camera perspective is such that the gameplay is primarily 2D, with just a little bit of depth. I think this was the perfect choice visually, but the result is that it can be really challenging to accurately judge where your character is in the depth plane. This wouldn't be a problem except that the game has several sequences where this is critical. The classic example of this for me is when I was walking along a pipe, with no enemies or time pressure, and I just steered the character off, falling to her death. This was a one-time event, but there were many (MANY!) times when I missed a jump or didn't avoid dangerous obstacles I had to thread my way through, not because I didn't know what I was supposed to do or mistimed something but because I couldn't tell where I was in relation to other things.

In addition to these (presumably) unintentional issues, there are also intentional issues that are core parts of the game design that lead to frustration. There are many (MANY!) sequences where the required timing is really tight, but also you are given very little time to anticipate or react. The result of this is that I often found myself redoing sections over and over. To be clear, Little Nightmares is not a difficult game, and the skill required to actually complete any of these sections isn't so bad. The problem, though, is that it feels like failure is anticipated or forced; you often can't really know what to do ahead of time until you've tried it and seen what happens or how you fail. Even this isn't inherently bad (if a bit old school), but it is bad in the context of what Little Nightmares is trying to do in terms of mood. It sets up these incredible situations and set pieces where I as a player was 100% engaged and was completely identifying with my character, but then when I failed in that context and had to redo things multiple times they lost all effectiveness. In a game like Ori I think this kind of game design can work, because the focus is on skill and platforming, but in a game like Little Nightmares where the focus is on the tension and atmosphere it felt very counterproductive to me.
(Also, related side note: There is a section where the controls of the flashlight change suddenly and without warning (and with an onscreen hint if you die enough times that doesn't make it clear that the control scheme is actually different). If you decide to play and find yourself getting really frustrated at one point because of the flashlight, just remember that it may be behaving differently from how it has the entire game!)

Again, I loved this game! But it feels dishonest to recommend it without at least giving some disclaimers about how frustrated it made me at times. I can't say enough good things about the atmosphere and what an artistic achievement it is, and if you're willing to look past some gameplay flaws there is a remarkable and memorable experience to be had.

148657831.review:
At the end of the day I liked this game, but there were portions of it that felt really annoying. It was mainly a game play and game design issue for me, everything else was spectacular. Tone, colors, grotesque and disturbing characters/plot, that's really what carried and sold the game for me.

But the game play and design...for goodness sake... a little bit of direction would have helped so as not to be lost all the time. I can not tell you how long it took me to realize I was supposed to climb up something, simply because the platform paths are not very "readable". On one hand, this is good for the immersion of the game - nothing really stands out all that much and it makes everything blend well together. On the other hand, you often find yourself trying again and again to figure out where you're supposed to go. 

I much prefer things like Mirror's edge's runner vision to show objects you can interact with or even GOW4's yellow painted cliffs/edges to show where to climb. I'm not saying make the paths you are supposed to platform super obvious like in GOW4 or in Mirror's Edge Runner vision, just that SOMETHING to indicate where to go or what to do would go a long way. It could even be something small like things falling to show there is more space above your area or to show a point of interest for the player. The strange depth perception, though unique and a positive trait of the game artistically, does add a layer of difficulty to platforming that can sometimes get frustrating. 

Now, there is also the evolution of the game play. Most games, they stay more or less the same throughout. Maybe you get new gear or learn a new move to keep things fresh as you progress, skill trees are examples of this since they add to the game without changing the overall game play. You'd still be punching, kicking, or casting spells... they just do different things now. But in this game, it kind of shifts into 4 genres and it does that pretty seamlessly. Each chapter is played differently from the next, the first is more like a stealth game, the second is more like a puzzle game, the third is a scrolling runner, and the last chapter is a boss battler. 

I personally had my gripes with this, though I do understand that it is a pretty cool concept to have your game change on you and then to suddenly adapt to the game's changes. (Inscryption is an example of this). The seamlessness of the genre transitions is what makes the game hard, even though it can be enjoyable. For example, after succeeding chapter 1, the stealth portion of the game, you move onto chapter 2 which deals more with puzzles and platforming. Because the way the game is played is now different in chapter 2, you realize that being really stealthy and playing things slow suddenly get you nowhere. In chapter 2, you are supposed to take big risks. This transition I actually did enjoy because both chapter 1 and chapter 2 felt like the same game. 

But come to chapter 3 and it felt like I was playing something different, even though it looked the same. In chapter 3, it is more of a runner-platformer. With far less puzzles, and where stealth is ultimately useless. This kind of felt like everything that I learned and the skills/tactics i developed in chapter 1/2 were pointless and thrown out the window. And so for me escaping chapter 2 felt more like the true ending since it rewarded all the work I did in both chapters. I was scared, disturbed, had adrenaline pumping, and then I was relieved. 

Then chapter 3 happened and I was deeply confused. I had no idea what the purpose of the game was anymore, no idea where I was going, why I was doing the things I was doing, and i had to shift from stealthy platforming puzzle solving tactics to ...running... and I did not feel rewarded after completing the chapter, I just really wanted it to be over because I got pretty frustrated and disheartened when it felt like nothing i learned in the past 2 hours of playing the game was working. It really felt like chapter 3 was only there for a major plot reveal so as to better tie in the story concept - which is already super vague. You can only build inferences on the story with subtle visuals followed by the 4-5 grotesque actions that take place.

I like when stories are like that, instead of huge lore dumps in a note or on the walls, you are allowed to fill in the spaces of the story yourself and it's pretty fun. Are they monsters? Aliens? what do they want with me? etc. If you are looking for something scary, this game is at most a 6/10 of being scary but a 11/10 at being disturbing.

148540782.review:
[h1]Of the Maw or The hunger nightmare[/h1]

I confess that the platform game isn’t a type I usually play. But when I succeeded to go across the adventure from start to finish, it gave me a unique and fascinating experience. What is the game about? About a sympathetic character clothed in a yellow raincoat named Six, whose tenacity is to escape from the ship called the Maw.

I consider that has been reflected about the game and a variety of analyses have been written. I’ll only limit myself to describing something about the game and my experience in it.

The game expresses a story and it does so through a non-verbal narrative. All this is realized through its scenography. The elements that comprise a particular scene attain to convey a feeling and communicate a fragment of the story. As the players proceed, they discover the fullness of the narrative plot.

How does it accomplish to perform such non-verbal narration? The game does this through three components that, when put together, create something integral. These are: the soundtrack, the non-verbal narrative and the art. They all depend on each other. If one is missing, the essence of its plot will not be understood. Or, to talk about non-verbal narrative, it rest on art and music, for example.

[h1]The surrealism of flesh[/h1]

The game poses a developed problem, the meat-consuming society. The way the topic is approached is from the perspective of a tot. As the description of the game indicates: overcoming infanthood fears through a nightmarish journey in a world inhabited by corrupted souls. With this premise, the game forms its plot through psychological features where images, allegories, signs and symbols will preponderate. Everything it wants to tell is done in each scenario. The experience is visual, but also aural.

Although the criticism is outstanding, its art also attracts an attention. It's inevitable not to notice the artistic inspirations but it bring about to obtain an original and unique art. Surrealism mainly be conspicuous, although it coalesces with other artistic inclinations and expressions to achieve a grotesque horror scenography in an eclectic way.

It’s true that most of us have a prejudice about how we relate a scene to a work of art that we know. For me, for example, each scene forms a theatrical piece where the character Six is always in a performance. The progressive linear movement of each scene leads to a sequence like a piece of footage. The game is well composed that achieves to convey a message-feeling and, at the same time, an openness to personal understanding reflected in each immersive experience.

The enemies are symbolic and allegorical, deformed and grotesque creatures, causing an aesthetic experience and a unique sensation in the game. I’m impressed by the details. In particular, a feeling of being someone small in a place subjugated by colossal items. The feeling of repugnance, starving, fragility, helplessness and defencelessness is revealed at all times. All of this gives the immersive, uninterrupted experience, in the gameplay that’s seek and hide, as well as solving some small puzzles while dwelling inside the feeling of being caught, cornered or confined.

Although the gameplay is basic, where sometimes the options of running or hiding turn out to be discernible at all times, keeps our breath, fear and suspense by having ominous enemies consigned in our path. SFX, or special sounds, accentuate the tension experienced during such a moment, such as sounds of heartbeats or moans. In this way, the non-verbal narrative of the game is realized together.

[h1]The nightmare waltz[/h1]

I’ll say something briefly about the third component of the game's formula, its soundtrack. Tobias Lilja is its composer. Each piece of music expresses us about the happenings that the protagonist faces, mainly hunger, emptiness and the loss of her infantile.

The music performs the rhythm of the waltz, but takes it to dissimilar gradual tones, namely, light tones to dark tones. The drama of Six moving to the rhythm of the waves swinging the boat. Also it attempts to prove the ladder of Six's journey as presented in the start menu. It’s the ambiguous journey of a shadowy character to the bright peak.

The musical elements are often heard as lullabies but are distorted or deformed. It’s audible at all times and accentuates as a dramatic force in certain parts of the story. It’s ambient, industrial, with electronic music structures, but always focusing on conveying an enveloping atmosphere to each situation as a soundscape for the scenography.

It also relates the plot and, at the same time, affords an intensity to tense the feelings. Sometimes it’s luminous, but other times strident, screaming, strong, dark, funereal and hopeless. It has been realized well in the soundtrack, where it bares the distortion of the protagonist succumbing in a world where corrupted souls live. It’s an excellent piece of music to emphasize the nightmare.

[h1]Little Lost Things[/h1]

As a brief review I discern what I’ve noticed, although many details are absconding. I liked the metaphor, symbolism and allegory of the game, especially the way it begins and closes its plot. It’s beautiful with those opaque, murky and enigmatic tones in the style of surrealism and a drop of pictorial realism.

The game is a unique, original experience with a developed theme that is absorbing at all times. The game is short, but if you halt to contemplate every detail like me, you’ll be in for an agitating surprise. That is, the surrealism felt in the Maw. A world full of paradoxes and contradictions.

You’re unrestricted to imagine and understand what the game wants to say. There’re no theories, but rather a diversity of interpretations, which the game accomplishes to bring about that plurality of understandings and feelings experienced in a grotesque, terrifying, cruel and, paradoxically, beautifully disturbing world.

To complete the adventure, the game contains DLC that intercepts Six's plot. I personally didn't play the mini-game, as I consider [i]Little Nightmares[/i] to be an integrated plot and a complete game. There is no need to add even more to something that’s already well done. Recommended, it’s often on sale.

[h1]Recommendation: 9/10[/h1]

148533204.review:
This is a super intriguing horror adventure game. The game can feel really scary at some points, but not enough to make anyone too scared to play. There are a lot of sudden deaths which are shocking, and mostly it is just very suspenseful. It won't make anyone cry.

All three of the DLCs felt like a part of the game though, so I definitely recommend picking those up through buying the complete edition or getting the expansion pass if you are looking for more. The base game by itself is super short, especially if you aren't looking for all of the collectibles and the three DLCs manage to add up to more content than in the original game (atleast for me).

The puzzles aren't super frustrating. When you first start, there is no specific tutorial to tell you what to do, but it is very easy to pick up. Interaction with everything is super easy, which makes every puzzle fun because you won't be stuck there thinking that you just don't understand how the game works. Admittedly, there were some areas I spent way too long at but not because I didn't understand a mechanic like some puzzle games can do. I never had to look up how to do any part of the game, which I usually do find myself doing as well.

It is just one of those breath of fresh air games, you can sit down and play and not worry about any commitment. You can stop at any time and come back later. It is also very relaxing because despite its malevolent theme, the game is good at immersion and just letting your mind go forwards.

As far as the DLC's go, I think they are a bit more scary than the base game specifically because of the dramatically darker lighting. The lights are completely off in many parts of the DLCs and you really do have to let yourself be "jumpscared" sometimes to figure out how to navigate through the dark levels.

Overall, I would give Little Nightmares a 9.5/10, this has been super enjoyable. The only thing preventing a 10/10 is the fact that I know Little Nightmares 2 is even better and I bet Little Nightmares 3 will be too, so I know this one isn't perfect.

148454919.review:
Short but sweet horror themed puzzle platformer where you play as a little girl in a raincoat trying to escape from a ship populated with grotesque, humanoid creatures trying to eat you. The puzzles themselves are pretty straightforward, but the true highlights of the game involve you playing hide and seek with these disgusting looking beings as you try to progress to the next area. Usually this just consists of you hiding under tables and counters as you wait for the monsters to pass, and then sprinting to the door as they realize where you are and start to give chase.

The atmosphere is this game's strongest asset. The lighting is excellent and the art direction really helps sell the nightmare vibe. My only complaint is that the controls are imprecise sometimes, especially when you need to quickly and desperately grab or pull an object as a creature is chasing you. Just be aware that trial and error is not uncommon here, although the game has frequent checkpoints so you don't have to retread too much ground.

I have honestly loved this game since i was younger and watching Dantdm play it the moment i found out about it.
I saw that it was on sale and thought 'hey, why not?' seeing as i had already borrowed the second game and gone in blind and had an absolute blast with it, getting every achievement.
At first, i had been annoyed by the pretty scuffed perspective and how easy it is to fall off platforms(compared to the sequel which also has some pretty annoying perspective at times) but, as i continued to play, I got more into it and way more used to it.
Odd to learn, easy to master, kind of a deal.

The narrative's ability to keep me captivated while also being very vague and puzzle-y is one of my favorite parts, especially when i can apply both literal and figurative theories to the game. Is this really happening? Is this just a child's perspective of the cruel world she lives in? Or is this truly about a child on a 'cruise' ship full of cannibals? It's all so interesting!
I do love the themes of innocence being crushed and molded into a rough bitterness just for Six to be able to survive, survival of the fittest and all that. It's a lot how our society handles child care, like with CPS and just blatant disrespect to even the idea of children.

Overall, very cool game and I am so excited for the 3rd game!

🎮 A Darkly Surreal Adventure Awaits 🎮

Let's dive into “Little Nightmares”, a game that seamlessly merges psychological horror and platforming in a world that’s not so much about outright fear, but a chilling, subtle disturbance.

Navigating the Shadowy Depths:

Unsettling yet Captivating Atmosphere: Embark on a journey where every element, from the grotesque environments to the eerie characters, brings you into a world that is as unsettling as it is darkly beautiful. It’s a world that doesn’t scare you but gently unnerves you at every dimly lit corner.

Subtle Thematic Undertones: Whilst there are light sprinklings of themes that might bring to mind various vices or moral decay (yeah, a bit of that sin-like flavor, but not overly so), the game doesn’t hinge on these. It’s more of an underlying note, subtly layered beneath the immediate perils and darkly intriguing environments you traverse.

From Prey to Predator:

A Morally Ambiguous Path: The game crafts an unusual trajectory for the player - moving from mere survival in a grotesque world to, potentially, becoming a part of its darkness. It’s an evolution that has you questioning morality and reveling, somewhat guiltily, in the darkening path your character treads.

Unexpected Satisfaction: There's an odd contentment in navigating through the darkness, and perhaps becoming it. The game doesn’t just make you a passive traveler but an active participant in its eerie world, and there's something darkly gratifying about that.

Engaging, Fearful Elegance:

A Different Shade of Horror: Shying away from standard horror tropes, Little Nightmares leans into a more nuanced, psychological fright. It’s a game that stays with you, not through jolts of fear but through lingering, disconcerting thoughts.

Effortless Controls & Haunting Melodies: Ensuring that your unsettling journey is smooth are the intuitive controls and a soundtrack that whispers chilling tunes into the immersive visuals, enhancing every shiver and moment of awe.

Little Nightmares isn’t a sprint through a haunted house; it’s more like a slow, contemplative walk through a beautifully grotesque landscape that stays with you, quietly lurking, long after the credits roll. It’s an invitation not just for horror fans but for anyone who enjoys a dip into darker, more introspective gaming experiences.

From one adventurer of dark tales to another, may your journey through this nightmarish world be as deeply engrossing as it is disturbingly delightful.

147878300.review:
[h1] Little Nightmares: A Creepy, Yet Uniquely Charming Nightmare [/h1]

Little Nightmares is not your typical horror game; it's a twisted journey that managed to invade my dreams and send shivers down my spine. Developed by Swedish studio Tarsier Studios, known for their work on the LittleBigPlanet series, it offers a distinctly unsettling experience wrapped in a whimsical package.

In this eerie puzzle-platformer, you play as a little girl named Six, navigating a nightmarish world with only a flickering lighter to guide you. The game's dreamlike logic constantly shifts your surroundings, leaving you feeling disoriented but captivated.

The unsettling atmosphere is where Little Nightmares excels. The grotesque yet strangely charming denizens of Six's world evoke the craftsmanship of Jim Henson, albeit with a nightmarish twist. While they repelled me, there was something tragically endearing about their misshapen forms, emphasizing Six's vulnerability.

What sets Little Nightmares apart is its use of color. Unlike many horror games that rely on monochrome palettes, this game incorporates vivid hues, even in its darkest corners. The contrast adds depth to the unnerving atmosphere, casting shadows and highlights that serve as hiding spots or lures for danger.

Sound design is equally impressive. Playing with headphones enhances the experience, immersing you in a world of creaks and squelches. Yet, silence is just as vital, signaling impending doom.

The gameplay evolves continually. What starts as stealth and evasion shifts seamlessly into environmental puzzles, from tossing cans to operating meat grinders. Later stages emphasize speed over stealth, ensuring you're always on edge.

Platforming serves as the game's unifying thread, and while keyboard controls proved frustrating, a controller smoothed the experience. The relatively short playtime, around five to six hours, prevents repetition. Challenges are diverse, and you'll likely die many times, with occasionally frustrating checkpoints and load times. However, these difficulties add to the sense of triumph upon success.

Little Nightmares' creepiness lingers because it masterfully balances bright moments with the ever-present threat of darkness. It's a game where the fear of the unknown is as potent as its gruesome imagery.

In the end, Little Nightmares successfully blended whimsy with horror, leaving me with lasting chills and a newfound appreciation for the nightmares that lurk just beneath the surface of our dreams.

I've had a love/hate relationship with this game from start to finish: in the first place, I'm not a fan of horror, --- I prefer to simply kill and destroy obstructions in my path, and actually do so in what passes for my nightmares IRL, --- but, it was recommended by a friend of a friend, and I could not pass up the opportunity to expand my horizons.

The context in which I would recommend this is as a puzzle game.  Yes, it is horror themed, --- and very well done at that, --- and it even makes some of the puzzles' solutions anti-intuitive, but I would say that the game was very well designed, overall, and would recommend it to fans of either genre.

However, it was the story progression and the ending that ultimately persuaded this review: --- there is a subtle change in the character "Six" throughout the story as a consequence of need and challenging their environment which leads up to the climactic ending which one simply must see for themselves...

147727310.review:
If you're looking for a review on this game you've come to the wrong place, but if you're looking for an outstanding pie recipe you've come to the right place.

Ingredients:

1. 6 tablespoons unsalted butter
2. 1/2 cup white sugar
3. 1/2 cup brown sugar
4. 1/4 cup water
5. 1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
6. 1 pinch salt
7. 5 apples - peeled, cored and sliced
8. 1 pastry for double-crust pie

Directions:

1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).
2. Combine butter, white sugar, brown sugar, water, cinnamon, and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil, remove from heat and set aside.
3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips, one at a time, into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.
5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie, coating the lattice, and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.
6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C), and bake until the crust is golden brown, the caramel on the top crust is set, and the apple filling is bubbling, 35 to 40 more minutes. Allow to cool completely before slicing.

147534756.review:
An excellent horror platformer!
The environments are indeed built in a whimsical way, though they fit right in with the beings that inhabit them. A clear strength of the game is the lighting, elevating the atmosphere greatly and tying into gameplay once in a while when you need to use your lighter to see where you are going.
Another strong aspect is the sound design and music. Especially in the last chapter did I take note of this for reasons that should be quite obvious when you get to that point yourself.
Told only through visuals the story is easy to grasp in broad strokes though some details require you to go through the game paying detailed attention to the environmental storytelling.
While short, clocking in at only a few hours for the base game, it is a good length for horror of this kind, keeping the tension high without becoming tiring.
Sometimes the controls felt a bit clunky, but this does help with immersion as Six is just a small individual in a large world. Additionally as becomes clear very quickly and is apparent through their stature they are not functioning at top capacity, so a little bit of clumsiness is to be expected.
The puzzles and platforming itself had a bit of challenge to them and required some trial and error once in a while, but were always doable within a few attempts. Never did I feel frustrated during the game as the checkpoints are placed very generously.
In summary the base game may be short, but the effort with which it was crafted is showing in every nock and cranny. It is an experience I can certainly recommend!

146740603.review: For a game that is loved this much i expected to be having a better time with it, but alas, little nightmares many strenghts get lost in frustration due to very poor controls, a lack of signposting/direction and unforgiving sections. It's a shame as the game looks and sounds amazing, the visuals and designs are all unique and memorable and the sound design is just right. Creaking doors and planks make way to terrifying screams belched out by horrendous abominations. The music is used sparringly but to great effect, especially in the rather memorable finale. Saddly the horrible controls leave much to be desired, such as getting stuck on little pieces of geometry at the worst possible time during a daring escape or failing countless jumps to the very poor depth perception. In fact depth perception or lack thereoff is a common occurance in this game, throwing an object at a button because you can't reach it is frustrating when it's this hard to get the direction right. All this things really add up to make the game feel clunky to play as a whole. It's also really unclear what to do or where to go at times. Since you can climb on some furniture but it isn't marked with a specific color or shine, so in a room with dozens of drawers you have to just guess which one you can climb. This is doubly annoying when you are running away from a monster, as these sequences are made to be very unforgiving, where even a moment's hesitation can get you killed. This took all the horror and terror out of these sequences and made them frustrating instead. I really hoped to like this game more, but in the end the audiovisual aspects aren't enough to alleviate the frustrations and the steep price that would make this game worth a purchase.

    - Without the DLC, the story doesn't feel complete.

Good game but today I am showing you an outstanding chocolate chip cookie recipe, you've come to the right place.
---------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Ingredients
1/2 cup (1 stick) unsalted butter
3/4 cup packed dark brown sugar
3/4 cup sugar
2 large eggs
1 teaspoon pure vanilla extract
1 (12-ounce) bag semisweet chocolate chips, or chunks
2 1/4 cups all-purpose flour
3/4 teaspoon baking soda
1 teaspoon fine salt

Directions
1. Evenly position 2 racks in the middle of the oven and preheat to 375 degrees F. (on convection setting if you have it.) Line 2 baking sheets with parchment paper or silicone sheets. (If you only have 1 baking sheet, let it cool completely between batches.)

2. Put the butter in a microwave safe bowl, cover and microwave on medium power until melted. (Alternatively melt in a small saucepan.) Cool slightly. Whisk the sugars, eggs, butter and vanilla in a large bowl until smooth.

3. Whisk the flour, baking soda and salt in another bowl. Stir the dry ingredients into the wet ingredients with a wooden spoon; take care not to over mix. Stir in the chocolate chips or chunks.

4. Scoop heaping tablespoons of the dough onto the prepared pans. Wet hands slightly and roll the dough into balls. Space the cookies about 2-inches apart on the pans. Bake, until golden, but still soft in the center, 12 to 16 minutes, depending on how chewy or crunchy you like your cookies. Transfer hot cookies with a spatula to a rack to cool. Serve.

5. Store cookies in a tightly sealed container for up to 5 days.

For a Rocky Road Bar:
1. Lightly butter a 9 by 13-inch baking pan. Make the batter as per cookie recipe and fold in 1 cup chopped walnuts along with the chocolate chips. Spread batter in prepared pan. Bake until the edges are light brown and the batter sets, about 45 minutes. Cool slightly and cover surface with 4 cups marshmallows and 1 cup chocolate chips. Broil at least 8 inches from the heat until marshmallows turn golden brown, about 2 minutes. (Keep an eye on the marshmallows, and turn the pan frequently--they go from golden to char in a wink.) Cool, cut and serve.

I want to mention that the aesthetic and gameplay are inspired by two pieces of media in particular which I really love, the video game, Inside, and the film, Spirited Away. Little Nightmares is great in a lot of ways, traversing its interesting and well designed environments paired with awesome atmosphere and intimidating threats, you've got a very good game. 145387844.review:
A thin creature in a yellow hood, no taller than a chair leg, runs through a dark corridor, lifts a door key with both hands like a weight, and battles a lady in a kabuki mask... "Alice Through the Looking Glass". "Spirited Away". Childhood fairy tales and forgotten fears of the dark night.

It's not scary for you, but rather eerie. As if the scary stories that kids told each other at night became reality. Little Nightmares turns you into a child, briefly bringing back the psychology that you dealt with through books and scientific knowledge.

But you can't get rid of the experience you've gained - you still remain an adult, you reflect. You don't see danger in dark rooms. And this double vision effect, where you are both a child and an adult at the same time, creates a truly unique atmosphere in Little Nightmares.

Community and Reviews: "Little Nightmares" is popular among players who are interested in horror and adventure games. The game's atmosphere, story and puzzles are positively evaluated by players.

Development and Publisher: The developer of the game is Tarsier Studios and the publisher is Bandai Namco Entertainment.

Conclusion: "Little Nightmares" is an impressive adventure-horror game set in a dark and eerie atmosphere. 145028232.review:
The game gives me a hard time when it comes to the decition wether to recommend or not. When it comes to more analytical judgment, a profound view at the craftmenship of making video games itself, perhaps even the world building and storytelling. This game would easily pass the few flaws it has and then going to be labled as horrofying yet thought provoking. But still there is another way of judgment. The way I felt when playing. A judgment based on my emotional response to everything. I´m not talking about the game looks gross therefor its bad. More the biggest emotion i associate with the game and how good are the pass onto me. Take it as the experience I had with the journey that the game offers me. When it comes to that, being honest, I only felt frustration. Pretty much from the start. 

For the moment, after beating the final DLC, I am sitting in a mixture of frustration and misfortune. I want to like the game. I truly want. But i cant. But lets start simple.

Little Nightmare is a puzzle Platformer, the story ist told without a spoken or written word and only experienced for the mindful player. When it comes to enviromental storytelling this game does everything right. Our character, Six, is left imprisont in somewhere deep down in the dark and frighting unkown. From the very first minute its clear that we need to escape this place. So our journey starts with many question and the fear of the unkown. As we progress we the world offers answer to some question and eacht steps forward till realization made me us uncomfortable knowing that it will take a lot to wistand the knowledge given by the final answer. The transition from being afraid to disgust at the very moment of Enlightenment is the strongest part of this games journey. And being honest at this point of my thoughts and writing i could leave and give a thump up. Because it is a thought provoking journey i could recommend to experience. 

However I dont wanna leave out all the rest. Since this game is a platformer this game is about moving from one side of the screen to another side. You need to climb, jump and run arround finding your way over many obstacles the game throws at you. So it can be assumed that good controls are what makes a platformer work. Yeah not Little Nightmares not for me. 

Moving the character feels unintutive and unresponsive. There where many situation I ended up twitching and jerking arround. From moments where i cant grab the edge and pull me up to grabbing the edge and letting go for no reason. I cant tell you how many death i experienced just by fighting the controller or the camera. 

The camera is kinda fix you look at a 3 dimensional world from the side scrolling perspective. While you can move away from the camera it makes jumps accros tiny beams and edges a torture. One moment you think you gonna make it only to end up missing by miles. Death is a common friend in this game.

And death is equaily frustrating. The game has checkpoints and you cant save manually. So when you die you either have to do a portion of the level again or in some cases the game saved seconds before an enemy appears on the stage right besides where it appears on the stage. Making it annoying hard to run away. As much as I like the design of the cook and janitor they are faster than you. Ok we are a little child. Yet one mistake in a chase scene means death. Not to meantion that the game only vagualy tells you what to do. More on that later. 

The AI of your hunters becomes aware of you in situation where it should be and i bugged it to the point it saw me thru walls always trying to grab me forcing me to restart the level. As said I admire there design, they dont speak but music gives them a voice. But chase music triggered and put on max while bugging out an AI breaks even me.

Another frustrating part are the puzzles. Its not that they are hard to solve its more that you sometime dont know what to do. Or in my case I did the right thing serveral times without resulting in what I wanted to happen. Leaving me searching for an answer online only to realize that i attempted to the right thing. Example would be the final fight against the janitor. Cornered evading to longs arm that want to pull you back into the darkness, I searched for the way forward. Two way presenting to survive this encounter. I either try to remove the obstacle blocking the door so it can fully close and trap the janitor outside or i can open a hatch that is a little elevated. I tried both for I dont know how many times. Nothing worked. I searched and tada I had to remove the obsticale. I felt betrayled and frustrated. Even with knowledge it didnt worked immediately. This problem repeats itself thru out the game and becomes a hinder in chases as you dont have time to check and try out everyting.

For all of that the game is short and the only length in playtime comes from moving back and forth in levels in order to solve a puzzle. Normally I would look over this and say its ok. But being fed up by frustration and a little anger every conspicuousness became a noticable problem that fed me more and more. No wonder that when i encountered a bug I kinda quitted the game for a moment. After being captured you end up locked in a cage. In a cutscene a person enters the room and pulls another cage away. The moment he grabbed the cage it collided with a third one flipping it over. I needed that cage to get out of my misery. Funny thing is when playing the DLC you end up in the same cutscene from a different perspective and it happend again. I am glad I only had to play the puzzle once and i needed to restart the level after the bug. 

Short word on the DLCs. They act as an addition to the story. You play a new character and experience his escape attempt which somtime crosses that of the main games character. The first of the three DLC puts you in a water based level with jumping and evading the granny. The granny is frighting but the jumping suffers the before mentioned camera and control problems. Failing means retaking a larger portion of the level. Overall its the introduction and the weakest of the three levels

Second DLC is the best for me. Not only you get the chance to interacted and utilize the cute looking nomes it had some cool puzzle sections with them. This little team up DLC is a good addition. Surprisingly i none of the mention bugs by some other players for that specific level. Still you technically have one room that you move across time and time again. For this DLC it works

For the third it didnt. The third DLC is placed again in one big room and you need to solve puzzles accross some side rooms. Its required to move some objects from one room to another. The book riddle ist the worst. If a friend that watch me playing didnt end my suffering I´d propably ask the internet for that. 

For my conclusion I wanna go back to my intial dilemma. I like the game for what it represents and I feal happy for the positive reception it received thru the years. This is one of my reason for my misfortune. I pitty myself for not enjoying the game. Looking bad it started with some red flags. I finished the game in my third attempt of playing it and I took breaks every 20 Minutes for atleast 15 Minutes for the first 1.5h of playing. With that i feel like I missed something because i still have some questions left that will never be answered. When it comes to judging it for me it narrows down to decide to recommend or not based on logical arguments forged by craftsmenship and the analytical view or my emotional journey i went thru. I know i could mix both things up and decide based on both parts, but both weight equally. So I have to put my heart onto one side of the scale. 

Which is going to be the emotional side. How I or how we feel is more important when playing that judging by some criterias. This leaves me saying I cant recommend the game. I suffered frustration and I dont wanna make other people suffer aswell.

144945986.review:
Title: Little Nightmares: Where Scares and Smiles Collide!
Rating: ★★★★★

"Little Nightmares" takes you on a rollercoaster ride through a world where creepy and quirky hold hands. It's like Tim Burton decided to throw a party, and you're invited!

Imagine a place where you're the underdog in a world of oversized oddities. From a raincoat-wearing kid facing towering terrors to outsmarting chefs with a taste for more than just cooking, this game keeps you on your toes, both literally and figuratively.

The visuals? They're so good, even the monsters would want to take a selfie! The attention to detail makes every corner a masterpiece of the macabre. And the eerie music? Let's just say it's like your favorite Halloween playlist on steroids.

The best part? "Little Nightmares" doesn't hold your hand – it's more like it drags you through its dark and twisted funhouse. But don't worry, the puzzles won't make your brain explode (well, most of them). They're just the right mix of challenging and "Aha! I'm a genius!" moments.

So, if you're up for a spooky, kooky adventure that'll make you laugh between screams, "Little Nightmares" is your golden ticket. Just remember to keep a nightlight on after you're done – those whimsical nightmares might just linger!

144933224.review:
Little Nightmares is a captivating game that expertly treads the line between horror and accessibility. Despite being tagged as a horror title, it offers a more manageable level of fear that can be enjoyed by a wide range of players.

The game's visuals and audio design are its crowning achievements. The hauntingly beautiful graphics bring the eerie world to life, while the carefully crafted soundscape intensifies the atmosphere. From the tiniest details to the sweeping landscapes, the game's presentation is top-notch.

Little Nightmares' gameplay is equally commendable. The puzzles are both engaging and solvable, never causing excessive frustration. This allows players to fully immerse themselves in the game's unsettling narrative without being hindered by overly complex mechanics.

In conclusion, Little Nightmares strikes the perfect balance between horror and gameplay. Its chilling charm, coupled with impressive visuals and audio, make it a game that shouldn't be missed. Whether you're a horror fan or a newcomer, this game offers an experience that will linger long after you've put down the controller.

An unsettling experience that doesn't overstay its welcome.
This game is an amazing, albeit short, experience.
 * Environments and character models are phenomenal.
 * World building and plot reveal are excellent.
 * Puzzles are creative, often unique, and legitimately challenging.
 * Platforming is OK (this part of the game is competent, but it does suffer a little bit from floaty jumps and squishy ledges. Nothing game-breakingly horrible, but it doesn't feel like a precision platformer)

All in all, this is one of those games I think is a must play for people, and there is no reason not to since it is quite short.

144522621.review:
Game still holds up in 2023. This game is demented and fun, albeit simple. The DLC really ties everything together, and I recommend getting them to complete the Little Nightmares experience. I'd even encourage you to play the DLC before the main story, and experience the horror for all it's worth. I've bought Little Nightmares 2, and downloaded the Little Nightmares comics, which I'm super excited to read. 

As a new-found achievement hunter, the achievements are totally accessible (except one). I got all the achievements and beat the game + DLCs in about 10 hours. However, it felt like 60 hours. Completing the achievements can be fun, and there do seem to be lore-related unlocks that you can only get through 100%-ing, but they aren't really explained. I have several scenes in my head that seemed significant, but I just don't understand the meaning. Now, my only complaint about the game is the achievement you unlock for completing the entire game in under 1 hour without dying. It's unreasonable, and just not fun. I didn't feel rewarded for completing it, I just felt desperate to get it done. 

Game is a 9/10, and seems to be heavily inspired by Spirited Away and Coraline — which adds to the dark coziness of this game.

First of all, I must clarify that I haven't finished it yet by myself.

BUT...

I've seen it played several times as I wanted to notice all the details, to try and understand what the meaning might be behind this masterpiece.

Some might say it's a game, but I would rather call it an interactive novel, an interactive work of art

Or better yet...

A SHOCKING ALARM CLOCK!!!!

I've read many theories about who Six is, what her past is, who are all these creatures that came on the ship called Maw.

While I've found some of them to be fairly accurate, I'd like to offer my own opinion (without knowing what happens in the second part, as I haven't watched it nor played it yet).

I think this work of art is an immersive experience, taking us for a ride into the modern world as we all know it today through the eyes of a little girl that might represent a whole generation, and attempts to address issues like education, child abuse, adults' greed and/or ignorance abou what happens around them, caring only about claiming more, trying to put their hands on the new generation without caring about it, except for the satisfy of their own NEEDS and HUNGER. 

On the other hand, this 'whole generation' experiences all these, from the time that lands on the vessel which might represent this world, and tries to survive without being devoured by the monsterous adults (each of them might possibly represent a milestone in this 'generation's journey).

There's that blindfolded janitor buried in his books who might represent the educational authorities, responsible for the future generations' education.
There are also those cookers that we can't see their real faces as they remain hidden under their disgusting masks, who are responsible for 'cooking' the 'meals' made of rotten meat and being served to the adults, satisfying their hunger as i mentioned above.
And then there's that geisha who can't stand looking her face in the mirror anymore, that might represent the previous generations who realized their mistakes and now they 're full of guilt for what they have caused.

The 'new generation' in the form of a little girl, survives from all of them and in the end steals the power for the 'previous generations' in the form of a guilty geisha
and exits the vessel while it kills any corrupted/greedy/disgusting adult she meets on her way.

I haven't digged deeply on deails yet such as what the gnomes might represent or why the little girl is named after Six, but that's my point of view on the bigger picture.

At some points, it reminds me the Plato's cave allegory for some reason.

I might missing something else, but trying to give my point of view in a nutshell here.

Now...

As a 3D artist myself, from an artistic point of view, the compositions, the environments, the dark and dissaturated color pallettes, the lighting, the animations, and the overall mood, makes it one of the best interactive piece of art i've ever seen.

Highly recommended for any adult and teen and may it help us realize and try to correct things in the right way, not for us but for the future generations.


Little nightmares are often infused with little hopes... it just needs some filtering to keep the hope alive.


11/10

144355011.review:
Titlu: O Călătorie Înfricoșătoare într-o Lume de Coșmar

★★★★★ Recomand

Little Nightmares este unul dintre acele jocuri care reușesc să creeze o experiență unică și memorabilă. Cu o grafică distinctă, o poveste misterioasă și o atmosferă înfricoșătoare, acest joc m-a captivat de la început până la sfârșit.

Designul vizual al jocului este remarcabil. Personajele și mediile sunt desenate cu detalii delicate și un stil artistic ce pare a fi scos dintr-un coșmar. Această abordare vizuală contribuie la crearea unei atmosfere opresive și tensionate care vă ține cu sufletul la gură.

Povestea este prezentată fără a folosi multe cuvinte, lăsându-vă să interpretați evenimentele și să vă imaginați ce se întâmplă în lumea bizară în care personajul principal navighează. Aventura micuțului personaj prin decoruri sinistre și străine este însoțită de o senzație persistentă de mister și descoperire.

Unul dintre punctele forte ale jocului este modul în care utilizează elemente de puzzle și platformă pentru a vă păstra implicarea. Rezolvarea enigmelor și navigarea prin medii periculoase vă testează abilitățile și adaugă o doză suplimentară de imersiune.

Atmosfera înfricoșătoare este completată de sunetul și muzica jocului, care vă învăluie într-un sentiment de neliniște și anticipare constantă. În fiecare colțișor al lumii jocului, vă puteți aștepta la surprize și momente care vă fac să săriți de spaimă.

Jocul are o durată de viață relativ scurtă, ceea ce poate fi un dezavantaj pentru unii jucători. Cu toate acestea, experiența în sine este atât de captivantă și intensă încât rămâne o amintire puternică mult timp după ce ați terminat jocul.

În concluzie, Little Nightmares este o bijuterie în lumea jocurilor indie. Dacă sunteți în căutarea unei aventuri înfricoșătoare, plină de mister și vizual impresionantă, acest joc merită cu siguranță o încercare. Deși este scurt, va lăsa o amprentă profundă în mintea și inima voastră, oferindu-vă o experiență unică și de neuitat.

Little Nightmares is an atmospheric gem that takes players on a dark and surreal journey into a world of twisted imagination. From its haunting visuals to its eerie sound design, this game succeeds in creating an unforgettable experience that will linger in your mind long after the credits roll.

The game's unique art style is an immediate standout, blending Tim Burton-esque aesthetics with a macabre charm. Every environment, every character, and every detail is meticulously crafted to evoke a sense of unease, drawing players deeper into its nightmarish setting.

As a puzzle-platformer, Little Nightmares challenges players to navigate through treacherous environments using wit and stealth. The puzzles are cleverly designed, often requiring creative thinking and experimentation. The stealth mechanics add an element of tension, making every encounter with the grotesque inhabitants of this world a heart-pounding experience.

One of the game's strongest aspects is its ability to tell a story without the use of traditional dialogue. Instead, the narrative unfolds through environmental storytelling and visual cues, allowing players to piece together the mystery behind the protagonist's plight. This approach adds an extra layer of intrigue and engages players in a way that few games achieve.

While the game's relatively short length might leave players craving more, its concise nature ensures that every moment is packed with significance. The pacing is expertly crafted, keeping players engaged from start to finish without ever feeling rushed.

However, it's worth noting that some players might find the gameplay mechanics a tad clunky at times, leading to occasional frustrations in certain scenarios. Additionally, the intentionally vague narrative might not resonate with everyone, as some players prefer more explicit storytelling.

In conclusion, Little Nightmares is an indie gem that excels at creating an atmosphere of dread and wonder. With its exceptional art style, clever puzzles, and haunting narrative, it offers a captivating experience that's perfect for those who appreciate a dark and unsettling journey into the unknown.

[h1]Little Nightmares[/h1]
[i]Diminutive Frightmares[/i]

[b]Little Nightmares[/b] is an enthralling and atmospheric puzzle-platformer that will leave players spellbound with its hauntingly unique visuals and eerie ambience. Developed by Tarsier Studios, this indie gem takes players on a macabre journey through a nightmarish world that's both unsettling and captivating.

Visually, [b]Little Nightmares[/b] shines. The art style is reminiscent of a Tim Burton movie, with its gloomy and grotesque character designs and intricately detailed environments. The attention to detail in the game's design is commendable, immersing players in a foreboding atmosphere that feels like a living nightmare. The use of lighting and shadows adds to the overall haunting experience, making every moment visually stunning and memorable.

The game's storyline is shrouded in mystery, which works to its advantage. Players control Six, a small, vulnerable protagonist who must navigate through the twisted halls of The Maw – a vast, derelict vessel inhabited by sinister and grotesque creatures. The lack of exposition allows players to unravel the narrative at their own pace, keeping them engaged and eager to discover the secrets hidden within the game's world.

Gameplay-wise, [b]Little Nightmares[/b] excels in creating a tense and suspenseful experience. Players must rely on their wits and stealth to avoid danger and solve environmental puzzles. The sense of vulnerability and helplessness is palpable, amplifying the fear factor and adrenaline rush as players stealthily evade the pursuing monstrosities. The game strikes a perfect balance between challenging puzzles and nerve-wracking encounters, keeping players on their toes throughout the adventure.

The sound design deserves special mention for enhancing the game's chilling atmosphere. The haunting melodies and spine-chilling sound effects further immerse players in the twisted world of [b]Little Nightmares[/b], creating an emotional connection with the game that lasts long after the credits roll.

However, [b]Little Nightmares[/b] isn't without its flaws. Some players might find the controls a bit clunky at times, leading to frustrating moments during high-stress situations. Additionally, the game's brevity might leave players wanting more, as the journey can be completed in just a few hours.

In conclusion, [b]Little Nightmares[/b] is a captivating experience that excels in creating an unforgettable and chilling adventure. With its striking art style, atmospheric world, and clever gameplay mechanics, it manages to immerse players in a hauntingly beautiful nightmare. Although a few shortcomings hold it back from perfection, the game's overall experience is undoubtedly worth exploring for fans of atmospheric and puzzle-driven adventures. [b]Little Nightmares[/b] successfully delivers a unique and unforgettable journey into the darkness.

[h1]One word or phrase to sum up the experience[/h1]
[i]Chillingly effective little horror puzzle-adventure-stealth game[/i]

[h1]Performance/Bug related incidents[/h1]
[i]None were experienced during my playtime with the game[/i]

143506820.review:
The single thing this game has going for it is the art style.  It's beautifully creepy and positively dripping with atmosphere. 
 And the music, while nothing special on its own, works wonderfully with the visuals to create an incredibly eerie and often tense sense of dread.  If this was a short film, I'd gush endlessly about how amazing it is and recommend it to everyone I know.  As a game, though, it's abysmal to play and too frequently more frustrating than fun.

I can't put my finger on exactly what it is, but where I loved Limbo and Inside, I found this game's trial-and-error insta-death gameplay to be child-punchingly maddening.  I think part of it is the camera/perspective.  The 3D aspect is nice, in theory, and does work to the visual aesthetics, but it makes some of the platforming and jumping you need to perform a hellish nightmare all its own.  It would be fine if it weren't so easy to just walk off platforms or if it was easier to line up jumps that, should you miss or fail to grab onto a ledge, see you fall to your death.  Or, worse, you grab onto a ledge only to find that, in this particular instance, your character refuses to pull itself up, leaving you no choice but to let go and, once again, plummet to your death.  And the fact that the camera pulls way back in some of these scenarios, more concerned with giving you a cinematic visual than a view conducive to the task at had is unforgivable.  Then factor in the inconsistent checkpoints - sometimes they start you right before the thing that killed you, while other times you have to trudge through the same rooms/hallways or go through the same slow and tedious climbing sequences - and it's the perfect recipe for a gameplay experience that absolutely sucks.

I'd also complain about the plodding character movement, but that seems like more an intentional choice rather than developer incompetence.  And, honestly, when everything lines up just right, when you don't get caught on a door frame or some little knobby bit of the level design, when you make that desperate last second jump and actually stick the landing, the character's sluggish movement makes for a genuinely tense horror movie moment of a narrow escape.  It's just a shame that the tension and scares too often come from the fear of potentially having to replay a garbage platforming/chase section for the fourth or fifth time.

I truly wanted to like this game.  I -should- like this game.  But I've just been struggling to find any amount of pleasure in the experience and don't even know if I'll finish it.  I may end up just watching a playthrough of the game because, again, the visuals are top notch and when I'm not fighting the camera perspective or the clunky controls, I'm actually able to appreciate what the developers were attempting to create.  So, that's my recommendation: skip the whole game/playing part and, instead, find a good no commentary playthrough on the internet so you can enjoy the best aspects of the game: the visuals and atmosphere.

[b]Camera Perspectives:[/b] Ever feel like you're being watched? The unique camera angles in this game will have you looking over your shoulder. They add to the immersion and make you feel like you're right there in the thick of it.

[b]Gameplay:[/b] Pattern escapes, anxiety-inducing moments, and a concept that's as creepy as it is captivating. This game doesn't just play; it [u]haunts[/u].

[b]Music:[/b] Top notch and extra creepy. The soundtrack adds layers to the wonder of the game, making your skin crawl in the best way possible.

[strike]Cons:[/strike] [spoiler]There are none. Seriously.[/spoiler]

[hr][/hr]

In conclusion, "Little Nightmares" is a must-play. Whether you're a fan of horror or just looking for something different, this game delivers. [b]Highly recommended[/b].

Grab your copy and dive into the nightmare. You won't regret it.

143010809.review:
[h1][b]Overall, the game is decent, but due to its shortcomings, it left a negative impression on me.[/b][/h1]

[list]
[*]In terms of genre, Little Nightmares is a puzzle-platformer. However, one of the key aspects of this genre - controls - was not executed well enough. It's precisely because of the character's unresponsiveness that some sections become painfully difficult to complete. Often, the character gets stuck or jerks when interacting with the environment, and he is unresponsive and incredibly slow.

[*]In this game, deaths are probably one of the most unfair. In platforming sections or critical moments, the controls can be unreliable, and your character might not perform the necessary actions. Enemies aren't inherently dangerous, and they could be relatively easy to avoid, but sometimes it's really difficult to understand when they might notice you. Moreover, escaping from monsters is practically impossible, except when a hiding spot is immediately available, which isn't always the case. In such a case, it would be appropriate to have at least some way to escape, so that it wouldn't be a 100% death and level restart. For me, this just makes the stealth mechanics very annoying. Basically, it's not such a big problem, but it just adds extra inconvenience to an already too short game that's supposed to leave a positive impression.

[*]The environments, no matter how beautiful they are, are difficult to navigate. Due to the odd 2D/3D perspective, it's challenging to orient yourself in relation to your character's plane. When jumping onto a platform, you might find yourself slightly to the left or right of it. Interactive objects blend seamlessly with the environment and are easy to miss. There are many situations where you think you can climb somewhere, but it's actually impossible. This is especially frustrating in chase scenes, where you need to make quick decisions.

[*]At times, the static camera takes very inconvenient positions, making it impossible to understand your character's location. If something obstructs your view, you can't see your character, which is annoying. Strangely, the camera isn't tied to enemies, so there are instances where they can see you, but you can't. While you can move the camera using arrow keys (up-down-left-right), it's more of a crutch. Doing this consistently is difficult, primarily because of the control issues.

[*]Due to the size of the locations, you often have to run from one end to the other for a significant amount of time (and frustratingly, most puzzles involve finding keys or similar items on the opposite end of the map). Here, the problem also lies in the fact that solving such puzzles can be quite lingering, as they are not always intuitively clear.
[/list]

I believe these are the main reasons I personally didn't enjoy the game. I'm sure it has found its audience, and labeling it unplayable would be inaccurate. However, I found it difficult to get positive emotions by playing it, and this review is based on my personal experience.

[h3][i][b]P.S.[/b] In my review I considered the full game with 3 DLCs. So, if you disagree with certain points, it's possible that it might be related to the fact that you haven't experienced the additional game content.[/i][/h3]
