142738105.review:
At first I was going to give this game a negative review but after sticking with it till the end I started to like it more and more and because I was so close to giving it that negative review, I wanted to write a full detailed review which I've never done before. I didn't enjoy playing it until the third chapter which was about 2 or 3ish hours in my first run. It's also worth mentioning that the game is short, about 4-5 hours, which isn't a bad thing personally for a $20 game but to some it may be a let down. After getting all achievements, I decided to write this review and now I'll get into the pros and cons.

PROS:
1. Cool environments and visuals 
2. Puzzles aren't too hard for the more casual gamers. I only needed to look up a guide once on how to progress because I didn't see a certain key hanging in chapter 3. 
3. Pretty chill overall and enjoyable
4. Great DLC. Personally I thought the DLC was a huge step-up from the base game and I highly recommend getting all three bonus DLC chapters. I liked the puzzles a lot more and the story of the DLC more than the base game. 


NEUTRAL STUFF:
1. Length of the game is definitely a point to make and could either be a plus or a minus to you.
2. The bonus masks you can buy for the cosmetics I didn't use at all but you may or may not like them and or want to use them. 
3. Price. It's only $20 USD, and the DLC adds a little more to the overall cost, but I think it's a fair price. I definitely think a lower price would make the game even more worth buying if it was priced as $15 or even $10. At the time of this review the game is on sale for only $5 and I think that makes it a definite buy.
4. The 4th and 5th chapters are really short compared to the first three chapters. They don't feel rushed, but kind of wished there could've been more.
5. Try to stick with it like I did until the end because hopefully you also change your mind and start liking it too!
6. Didn't feel scary at all to me but I'm also probably not the target audience. Could be a decent spook for the easily frightened or for younger audiences. A great horror game to me is like Outlast or Amnesia TDD (2 of my favorites) so the horror element wasn't really a thing that stuck out to me. 
7. There is a story. It is told through cutscenes and suggestive themes because there are no text or words to read or listen to. The story is more of a "watch and learn" type of thing than a "read this" type of story.

CONS: 
1. The controls ABSOLUTELY SUCK. This is the huge major let down of the game. There is a lot of parkour and with bad controls this is a nightmare and the major reason why I almost stopped playing the game entirely. In the DLC the controls did feel better, but that might just be me.
2. The camera. Doing puzzles, chases, and parkour with this camera is also a negative. Granted, it's not that bad all the time, but being precise trying to line up a jump or a slide in a chase sequence, the camera can easily get you killed. 
3. Glitchy Hitboxes. I'm not sure if these are bugs per say, but many times the hitboxes of enemies and objects feel horrible and unfair. Particularly with the Janitor (long arms guy) even outside of his long reaching arms, he can still grab you. The death animations also didn't line up a lot and I believe this has to do with the glitchy hitboxes because when the janitor would grab me sometimes I would float in mid air and not in his hands for the death animations and then be killed. Crawling through vents I got stuck on bolts which are for added detail but why do they have collision? Going upstairs I got stuck on walls right next to stairs at times as well. 

Tips because I do recommend you buy it:
1. Your character does have limited stamina. I didn't notice this until my Hard to the Core run, which was my last time playing the game, but after running for a long time your character does start to breathe harder and will bend overt to catch their breath. You do slow down in running speed and that can and will cause you to die in chases at times. 
2. You can sneak faster if you hold crouch and sprint at the same time as well as in vents when you are already crouched, you just have to hold sprint to move faster. You're welcome. 
3. It's hard to give a good answer on B-hopping but it does make you go faster from my experience. If you only bhop, you will get caught in chases and start to slow down. From what I've noticed, Sprinting at full speed (max stamina, no heavy breathing) and doing 2 bhops is best to escape chases and go faster in general but more than that and you'll slow down. I believe it's because when land from jumping, your character will stop for a split second which lets bosses catch you. 

Overall a decent to good experience and I'm no professional game critic, but I would rate it a low B tier game if I was to put it on a tier list. I think the 81 that Metacritic gave it is accurate in judging its quality in case you needed that number value/100. Personally the controls are the major flaw that hold this game back from being a solid B tier.

142649440.review:
A very imaginative side scroller with a hint of horror and puzzles along the way.

My play time includes watching a 2 hour movie and 2 episodes of One Punch man, so yes, the game is rather short. Around 5 to 7 hours is more accurate to portray the time I actually spent ''playing'' the game. I suppose the main reason why I went ahead and went to do something else is that I find one hit mechanics rather frustrating. So as to not ruin the wonderful experience that Little Nightmares has to offer, I just went and did something else for a bit, and came back with a fresh outlook. 

You will die, and instantly at that, to some bosses... or rather encounters. It can be annoying to figure out what it is you need to do, but once you know, it's just a matter of timing it right and moving on becomes easy.

142260503.review:
Okay so there were a few things that I liked about it:
-The Monsters' designs were okay, nothing special, but what sold them is the animation and the sound design, those were pretty cool
-Some of the environments are great looking
-It's really short. Hooray for short games!
-The fat guys were pretty funny.
okay that's about it

The yuckies:
- The controls are actually embarrasingly bad and the only thing redeemable about them is that the game is really short so you just might be able to suffer through to the end of the game without giving up on it. Your character's animations are weirdly noticeably less smooth than the monsters which is pretty weird but I guess it's purely visual so it's whatever I guess. The bigger problem is that the 3D perspective is really bad and makes walking or jumping in straight lines really difficult. There were multiple instances where I had to re-do a chase sequence not because I didn't know where to run/jump (though there are some of those too), but because my character just decided to walk off from a straight pipe and die, or jumped diagonally instead of straight ahead.

-Ledge grabbing is really inconsistent. The game lets you grab pretty much every ledge, but then it's really selective about where you can climb up from a ledge or even just move along it. It's really weird and makes the interactions with the world feel inconsistent sometimes.

-The constantly in-motion camera makes the simplest movement feel imprecise and wonky, and it's only worse when you have to make a simple jump or walk in a straight line which is like 70% of the game (I get that the camera is supposed to sway like a boat and have a handheld feel, but it's a big part of the horrible gameplay feel so I don't think this stylistic choice was worth it)

- The story is non-existent. It's not that it's confusing, there just an absence of narrative beats or elements for a story to happen. Throughout the whole story we learn about the main character that he's really hungry and then eats a superpower at the end because it was just laying there right when his lil' tummy was rumblin. And that's the end of the story. Gameplay is usually much more important for me in video games, but 1) I'm not ignoring stories either and 2) the gameplay is really bad, so I was searching for anything I could get. I'm sure there's a masterpiece of a story in all the DLC, but what I've experienced in the base game doesn't even motivate me to google if that's the case.

-The sound design is weird sometimes. There was a level where it was really important that you walk on carpets to dampen your footsteps, which was cool, but I guess it mattered only in that one level because you can just walk around monsters in later levels and make a bunch of noise and they're not interested in you at all. That's more of a nit-pick, but it was weird to me that I can just run around huge monsters without a care in the world, becasue just 20 minutes ago I had to sneak around constantly. Also the music is bland. I guess the game doesn't emphesise music that much in favor of ambient sound design, which is a good idea overall, but when they hit you with da main song, it's jarring and it's not very good either.

- The amount of times where I was escaping from a monster and my character suddenly snaps to it's hand was at least enough for me to notice that it's a trend, it made a lot of failures feel cheap.

Maybe get it on a sale, at least it's short so you won't be wasting that much time.

141605641.review:
Little Nightmares, developed by Tarsier Studios, is a mesmerizing puzzle-platformer that invites players into a dark and atmospheric world filled with twisted imagery and unsettling encounters. This hauntingly beautiful game takes you on a journey through the nightmares of a young child, blending elements of horror, suspense, and puzzle-solving to deliver an unforgettable experience.

From the moment you step into the shoes of Six, a small and vulnerable protagonist, you're immersed in a nightmarish realm known as The Maw. The visual design of Little Nightmares is nothing short of breathtaking, with its handcrafted environments, detailed character designs, and atmospheric lighting creating a chilling atmosphere that evokes a sense of unease and wonder.

The gameplay revolves around exploration, puzzle-solving, and stealth. As you navigate the treacherous halls of The Maw, you'll encounter grotesque and menacing creatures, each with their own distinct design and behavior. The puzzles are cleverly designed, requiring keen observation and logical thinking to progress. The sense of vulnerability and tension is palpable, as you must carefully navigate your surroundings, avoiding detection and finding ways to overcome the challenges that lie in your path.

One of the game's strengths is its ability to convey a sense of dread and anticipation without relying on jump scares or excessive gore. Little Nightmares relies on subtle visual cues, haunting sound design, and ambient music to create an atmosphere that is both unsettling and captivating. Every creaking floorboard and eerie whisper adds to the immersive experience, immersing you in a world where the line between dreams and nightmares blurs.

The story of Little Nightmares is presented in a cryptic and enigmatic manner, allowing players to piece together the narrative through subtle environmental storytelling and symbolism. It's a tale that explores themes of innocence, fear, and the darkness that resides within us all. The game's brevity works in its favor, leaving room for interpretation and encouraging multiple playthroughs to uncover hidden secrets and additional layers of the story.

Visually, Little Nightmares is a work of art. The handcrafted environments are meticulously detailed, from the grimy kitchens to the towering bedrooms. The character animations are fluid and expressive, capturing the essence of both the childlike wonder and the sinister nature of the world. The attention to detail in the art direction creates a visually striking experience that will leave a lasting impression.

In conclusion, Little Nightmares is a masterclass in atmospheric storytelling and visual design. It presents a chilling and thought-provoking journey through the nightmares of childhood, filled with puzzles, suspense, and a pervasive sense of unease. Whether you're a fan of puzzle-platformers or simply appreciate games that push boundaries in terms of artistry and atmosphere, Little Nightmares is an unforgettable experience that will linger in your mind long after the credits roll.

141305666.review:
Little Nightmares is a hauntingly beautiful and delightfully unsettling journey that plunges you into a world of nightmares straight out of your darkest childhood fears. With its unique visual style, atmospheric sound design, and intuitive gameplay, it's a game that immerses you in a chilling and captivating experience.

From the moment you take control of Six, a small raincoat-clad protagonist, you're transported to a realm where the line between dreams and nightmares blurs. The art direction in Little Nightmares is a true marvel, with its twisted and grotesque environments that evoke a sense of both wonder and dread. The attention to detail in the visual design, from the dilapidated furniture to the grotesque inhabitants, creates a truly immersive and macabre world.

The gameplay mechanics in Little Nightmares strike a perfect balance between exploration, puzzle-solving, and stealth. Each area is a meticulously crafted playground of nightmares, filled with cleverly designed puzzles and lurking dangers. As you navigate through the dimly lit corridors and avoid the clutches of grotesque beings, you can't help but feel a constant sense of tension and unease. The game masterfully builds suspense, making each encounter a heart-pounding and adrenaline-fueled experience.

One of the standout features of Little Nightmares is its ability to tap into your deep-rooted fears and emotions. The narrative unfolds through subtle environmental storytelling, leaving you to piece together the dark and twisted world you find yourself in. It's a game that invites interpretation and introspection, touching on themes of isolation, vulnerability, and the loss of innocence.

The sound design in Little Nightmares deserves special recognition for its contribution to the game's eerie atmosphere. The haunting melodies, ambient noises, and the subtle whispers in the dark all add layers of immersion and further intensify the feeling of dread. Each creaking floorboard, distant wail, and spine-chilling screech resonate in your ears, creating a haunting auditory experience.

Little Nightmares may be a relatively short experience, but it leaves a lasting impression. The combination of its atmospheric visuals, engaging gameplay, and thought-provoking narrative make it a standout in the realm of horror and psychological games. It's a testament to the power of simplicity and the ability of video games to evoke emotions and create a truly immersive experience.

In conclusion, Little Nightmares is a captivating dive into the shadows of childhood fears. With its haunting visuals, clever puzzles, and atmospheric sound design, it's a game that stays with you long after you've turned off the console. If you're a fan of atmospheric horror and enjoy thought-provoking experiences that delve into the depths of the human psyche, Little Nightmares is an absolute must-play. Just be prepared to face your fears and uncover the unsettling truths that lie within the darkness.
